description: From Middle English puple, peple, peeple, from Anglo-Norman people, from Old French pueple, peuple, pople, from Latin populus (“a people, nation”), from Old Latin populus, from earlier poplus, from even earlier poplos, from Proto-Italic *poplos (“army”) of unknown origin. Gradually ousted native English lede and, partially, folk.

Originally a singular noun (e.g. The people is hungry, and weary, and thirsty, in the wilderness –2 Samuel 17:29, King James Version, spelling modernized), the plural aspect of people is probably due to influence from Middle English lede, leed, a plural since Old English times; see lēode.

entries.meaning: Used as plural of person; a body of human beings considered generally or collectively; a group of two or more persons.
examples: There were so many people at the restaurant last night.

entries.meaning: (countable) Persons forming or belonging to a particular group, such as a nation, class, ethnic group, country, family, etc.
A group of persons regarded as being employees, followers, companions or subjects of a ruler.
A person's ancestors, relatives or family.
examples: My people lived through the Black Plague and the Thirty Years War.

entries.meaning: The mass of a community as distinguished from a special class (elite); the commonalty; the populace; the vulgar; the common crowd; the citizens.

verbs.description: people (third-person singular simple present peoples, present participle peopling, simple past and past participle peopled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To stock with people or inhabitants; to fill as with people; to populate.
examples: He would not be alone, who all things can; / But peopled Heav'n with Angels, Earth with Man.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To inhabit; to occupy; to populate.
examples: […]  / As thick and numberless / As the gay motes that people the Sun Beams, /  […]

entries.meaning: (rare, informal) To interact with people; to socialize.
examples: My head tilted as Calvin said, "Don't worry about him. He just doesn't people well.
The fuck? I people. Sometimes. With people I know.
